description.narrative: FAO’s Global Goals are: 1. Eradication of hunger, food insecurity and malnutrition, progressively ensuring a world in which people at all times have sufficient safe and nutritious food that meets their dietary needs and food preferences for an active and healthy life; 2. Elimination of poverty and the driving forward of economic and social progress for all, with increased food production, enhanced rural development and sustainable livelihoods; 3. Sustainable management and utilization of natural resources, including land, water, air, climate and genetic resources for the benefit of present and future generations. Based on the global goals, FAO has formulated five strategic objectives: 1. Contribute to the eradication of hunger, food insecurity and malnutrition 2. Make agriculture, forestry and fisheries more productive and sustainable 3. Reduce rural poverty 4. Enable more inclusive and efficient agricultural and food systems 5. Increase the resilience of livelihoods to threats and crises The Strategic Framework also includes a sixth, broad objective on technical quality, knowledge and services (including cross-cutting themes) that is designed to cover FAO’s internal capability to deliver its strategic objectives. The objectives are in alignment with FAO’s commitment to working in partnerships. In humanitarian crises, FAO’s main components are: To help people to anticipate and prepare for crises; To respond fast to crises; To seek to reduce risks and address vulnerabilities. The humanitarian operations are usually related to the 5th strategic objective which has the four following organizational outcomes (OO): OO1 - countries and regions have legal, policy and institutional systems and regulatory frameworks for disaster and crisis risk management for agriculture, food and nutrition; OO2 - countries and regions deliver regular information and trigger timely actions against potential, known and emerging threats to agriculture, food, and nutrition; OO3 - countries apply prevention and impact mitigation measures that reduce risks for agriculture, food and nutrition; OO4 - countries and regions affected by disasters and crises with impact on agriculture, food and nutrition are prepared for, and manage effective responses. At the next level in the FAO Strategic Framework, there are a number of outputs pertinent to humanitarian action, such as: Output 4.1: Humanitarian action effectively protect lives and livelihoods of farmers, herders, Fishers, forest- and tree-dependent communities and marginal groups in times of crises. Output 3.1: Strategies and related interventions improve the resilience of livelihoods systems at risk through prevention and mitigation efforts that minimize the potential impacts of disasters and crises on agriculture food and nutrition at national, subnational and community levels. Output 2.2: Improved capacities of countries and communities to identify monitor and evaluate risks; conduct needs assessment and response analysis; and act on impending threats to agriculture, nutrition, food security and food safety (and related public health issues). Output 3.3: Conflict-sensitive programmes on agriculture, food and nutrition reduce the risks of localized conflicts relating to access to grazing, forest and farming lands, fishing grounds, water, trees and other natural resources. As Sida support FAO’s operations through a variety of different projects in different contexts, this appraisal does not include an overarching results framework. In the annual follow up reading up to Sida’s conclusion on performance all individual project reports will be analysed and assessed.

Detta beslut avser ”Beslut om insats” (Insatshanteringsregeln 2.9 §) mellan Sida och FAO för att möjliggöra humanitärt stöd i fyra kriser 2021.
Beslutet omfattar finansiellt stöd till FAO om totalt 102 000 000 kronor, varav 94 000 000 kronor år 2021.
Sidas humanitära enhet har under 2020 genomfört en översyn av samtliga strategiska partners i syfte att säkerställa samarbete med de mest relevanta och effektiva humanitära aktörerna för genomförandet av Sveriges humanitära strategi genom Sida (2021-2025). Som ett resultat av översynen har Sida beslutat att bereda ny insats och ingå nytt strategiskt partnerskap med FAO, se beslut 2021-000057.
Syftet för beslutet är att stödja FAO:s humanitära verksamhet under 2021 samt ingå strategiskt partnerskap för perioden 2021 – 2025.
Genom stödet till FAO kommer Sida under 2021 bidra till FAO:s operativa verksamhet i Afghanistan, Nigeria, Somalia och Sydsudan. Vidare kommer Sida bidra med medel till FAO:s snabbinsatsmekanism SFERA samt med medel till det globala livsmedelsklustret.
Stödet utbetalas i början av året för att FAO ska ha förutsättningar att planera och genomföra humanitära insatser utan fördröjning. FAO omsätter regelmässigt utbetalda medel i nära anslutning till utbetalning och förbrukar gåvomedel inom verksamhetsåret.

The Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) is a specialised agency of the United Nations that leads international efforts to defeat hunger. The organisation's goal is to achieve food security for all and make sure that people have regular access to enough high-quality food to lead active, healthy lives. With over 194 member states, FAO works in over 130 countries worldwide.
FAO works side by side with the other two Rome-based UN agencies – the World Food Programme (WFP) and the International Fund for Agricultural Development (IFAD) to promote food security by alleviating hunger through emergency food assistance as well as more long-term support to eliminate the root causes of food insecurity. While WFP’s main comparative advantage lies in its capacity for large-scale food response, logistics, telecommunications and procurement capacity, the advantage of FAO lies in its role as the world’s agricultural knowledge agency with its unique agricultural expertise but also in its holistic approach to humanitarian crises, which includes analysis of the entire food system, including cultivation, harvesting, processing, packaging, transporting, marketing and consumption.
FAO also plays an important normative role, through international agreements, codes of conduct, and voluntary guidelines as well as policy dialogue at global, regional and national levels and advocacy in areas relevant to FAO’s mandate.
Sida’s humanitarian allocation to FAO in 2021
Sida´s humanitarian assistance is based on the four humanitarian principles, in particular impartiality, with its compelling urge to ensure that humanitarian action is carried out based on needs alone, giving priority to the most urgent cases of distress. Hence, Sida’s allocation methodology is grounded in several objective indicators such as; the scale of humanitarian needs (number of people in need), the severity of humanitarian needs (including food insecurity/IPC levels), the number of people targeted for the humanitarian response, the financial coverage of the respective humanitarian appeal, national capacities to respond and underlying risks, as well as distinct indicators related to forgotten crises. The allocation and subsequent disbursement of funds takes place in the beginning of the year to ensure predictability for Sida’s strategic humanitarian partners and to allow for optimal operational planning.
Based on Sida's humanitarian needs-based allocation process in late 2020 the following is proposed for FAO in 2021:
- Annual Projects/Programmes in line with Humanitarian Response Plans (usually 12 months) - 67 000 000 SEK - Rapid Response Mechanism (SFERA) - 25 000 000 SEK - Method Development and Capacity-Building - 2 000 000 SEK
This means that the total initial contribution to FAO in 2021 amounts to 94 000 000 SEK.

description.narrative: Från 1:a januari 2019 till och med 31:a mars 2020 bidrog Sida med 249 miljoner kronor till 17 humanitära insatser implementerade av FAO över hela världen, varav tio i Afrika (Kamerun, Centralafrikanska republiken, Tchad , Mali, Niger, Nigeria, Somalia, Uganda och Zimbabwe); två i Asien (Afghanistan och Nordkorea); två i Mellanöstern (Irak och Syrien); en i Centralamerika (Guatemala/Nicaragua); samt stöd till det globala livsmedelsklustret. Nedan följer några exempel från de genomförda projekten: - Sida-finansiering i Afghanistan bidrog till att tillhandahålla akut livsmedelsbistånd för jordbrukare och boskapsskötare som drabbats av torka. Projektet bidrog till att stärka kapaciteten i jordbruket och förbättra livsmedelstryggheten. Projektet nådde 52 800 människor med exempelvis tillgång till utsäde och djurfoder samt teknisk utbildning kring boskapsskötsel och jordbruksproduktion. - I Centralafrikanska republiken finansierade Sida ett projekt som nådde 14 200 hushåll med utsäde i syfte att förbättra livsmedelstryggheten och bidra till en återställd jordbruksproduktion. Sida finansierade även utbildningar kring jordbruksproduktion. - I Nigeria har det Sida-finanseriade FAO-projektet bidragit till ökad livsmedelstrygghet och förbättrade nutritionsnivåer samt stärkt skydd för 27 330 hushåll utsatta för konflikt genom kontantbaserat stöd, vaccinationskampanjer för boskap, tillhandahållande av utsäde, upprättande av grönsaksodlingar samt insatser för lokalt sparande och lån (VSLA). - I Somalia finansierade Sida två projekt, varav ett bidrog till stärkt analytisk kapacitet för att förebygga naturkatastrofer och försämrad livsmedelstrygghet samt kapacitetsutveckling av nationella institutioners kapacitet inom detta område. Det andra projektet bidrog till förbättrad livsmedelstrygghet för 10 140 jordbrukande hushåll samt till att stärka jordbrukets motståndskraft mot framtida kriser och katastrofer.
